meanings.def: used to say that no other or others of the same group exist or are there
examples: She's their only daughter.
We were the only people there.
His only answer was a grunt.
I was not the only one with moist eyes at the end of the film.
The only way he can express himself is through violence.
The only reason for this crisis is poor planning.
This might be the only time in my life I have this opportunity.
The only real difference between them is their packaging.
That's the only possible explanation I can find.
We have no choice. The only other option is to die.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody/something is the best and you would not choose any other
examples: She's the only person for the job.
Joe's diner is the only place to eat when you 're staying in New York.

meanings.def: officially recognized but not existing in reality
examples: He's party leader in name only.

meanings.def: used to emphasize that somebody is famous
examples: Here she is, the one and only Rihanna!

meanings.def: used before mentioning a worry or problem you have with something
examples: I'd love to come—the only thing is I might be late.

examples: Here she is, the one and only Rihanna!

meanings.def: nobody or nothing except
examples: There are only a limited number of tickets available.
The bar is for members only.
You only have to look at her to see she doesn't eat enough.
Only five people turned up.
They are second only to Nike in the sale of running shoes.
The bill will apply only to young workers.

meanings.def: in no other situation, place, etc.
examples: I agreed, but only because I was frightened.
Use pesticides only when necessary.
Paul has a mobile phone but uses it only in emergencies.
Children are admitted only if accompanied by an adult.

meanings.def: no more important, interesting, serious, etc. than
examples: It was only a suggestion.
Don't blame me, I'm only the messenger!
He was only teasing you.

meanings.def: no more than; no longer than
examples: She's only 21 and she runs her own business.
I've only ever seen her once.
Only about 20 per cent of the crop is exported.
It only took a few seconds.
It took only a few seconds.
Each offer is valid only for one day.
She confirmed that the dog incident occurred only once.

meanings.def: not until
examples: We only got here yesterday.
The black-faced lion tamarin of Brazil was only recently discovered.
(formal) Only then did she realize the stress he was under.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody can do no more than what is mentioned, although this is probably not enough
examples: We can only guess what happened.
He could only watch helplessly as the car plunged into the ravine.
I only hope that she never finds out.

meanings.def: used to say that something will have a bad effect
examples: If you do that, it will only make matters worse.
Trying to reason with him only enrages him even more.

meanings.def: used to mention something that happens immediately afterwards, especially something that is surprising, disappointing, etc.
examples: She turned up the driveway, only to find her way blocked.

meanings.def: used to say that you wish something was true or that something had happened
examples: If only I were rich.
If only I knew her name.
If only he'd remembered to send that letter.
If only I had gone by taxi.

meanings.def: used to emphasize that something else is also true
examples: She not only wrote the text but also selected the illustrations.
He not only read the book, but also remembered what he had read.
Bilingual children do better in IQ tests than children who speak only one language. In addition/What is more, they seem to find it easier to learn third or even fourth languages.
Learning another language not only improves children’s job prospects in later life, but also boosts their self-esteem.
Teaching children a second language improves their job prospects in later life. Other benefits include increased self-esteem and greater tolerance of other cultures.
Another/One further/One additional reason for encouraging bilingual education is that it boosts children’s self-esteem.

Studies suggest that bilingual children find it easier to learn additional languages. There is, moreover, increasing evidence that bilingual children perform better across a range of school subjects, not just foreign languages.
His claim that children find bilingual education confusing is based on very little evidence. Moreover, the evidence he does provide is seriously flawed.

Research has shown that first-language development is not impeded by exposure to a second language. Furthermore, there is no evidence to support the claim that children find bilingual education confusing.

meanings.def: to be in love with only one particular person
examples: He's only ever had eyes for his wife.

meanings.def: not long ago/before
examples: We've only just arrived.

meanings.def: almost not
examples: He only just caught the train.
I can afford it, but only just.

meanings.def: very
examples: I was only too pleased to help.
Children can be difficult as we know only too well.

meanings.def: used to say that you will have to wait for some time to find out the result of a situation
examples: Only time will tell if the treatment has been successful.

meanings.def: young people should enjoy themselves as much as possible, because they will have to work and worry later in their lives
